$.comment: The $ object provides a number of debugging facilities and informational methods.

decimalPoint.comment: The character used as the decimal point character in formatted numeric output.

engineName.comment: The name of the current ExtendScript engine, if set.

error.comment: The most recent run-time error information. Assigning error text to this property generates a run-time error; however, the preferred way to generate a run-time error is to throw an Error object.

fileName.comment: The file name of the current script.

flags.comment: Gets or sets low-level debug output flags. A logical AND of bit flag values: 0x0002 (2): Displays each line with its line number as it is executed. 0x0040 (64): Enables excessive garbage collection. Usually, garbage collection starts when the number of objects has increased by a certain amount since the last garbage collection. This flag causes ExtendScript to garbage collect after almost every statement. This impairs performance severely, but is useful when you suspect that an object gets released too soon. 0x0080 (128): Displays all calls with their arguments and the return value. 0x0100 (256): Enables extended error handling (see strict). 0x0200 (512): Enables the localization feature of the toString method. Equivalent to the localize property.

global.comment: A reference to the global object, which contains the JavaScript global namespace.

hiresTimer.comment: A high-resolution timer, measuring the time in microseconds. The timer starts when ExtendScript is initialized during the application startup sequence. Every read access resets the timer to Zero.

includePath.comment: The path for include files for the current script.

level.comment: The current debugging level, which enables or disables the JavaScript debugger. One of 0 (no debugging), 1 (break on runtime errors), or 2 (full debug mode).

line.comment: The current line number of the currently executing script.

locale.comment: Gets or sets the current locale. The string contains five characters in the form LL_RR, where LL is an ISO 639 language specifier, and RR is an ISO 3166 region specifier.Initially, this is the value that the application or the platform returns for the current user. You can set it to temporarily change the locale for testing. To return to the application or platform setting, set to undefined, null, or the empty string.

localize.comment: Set to true to enable the extended localization features of the built-in toString() method.

memCache.comment: The ExtendScript memory cache size, in bytes.

os.comment: The current operating system version information.

screens.comment: An array of objects containing information about the display screens attached to your computer. Each object has the properties left, top, right, bottom, which contain the four corners of each screen in global coordinates.A property primary is true if that object describes the primary display.

strict.comment: Sets or clears strict mode for object modification. When true, any attempt to write to a read-only property causes a runtime error. Some objects do not permit the creation of new properties when true.

version.comment: The version number of the ExtendScript engine. Formatted as a three-part number and description; for example: "3.92.95 (debug)".

about.comment: Shows an About box for the ExtendScript component, and returns the text for the box.

bp.comment: Breaks execution at the current position.

args.condition: A string containing a JavaScript statement to be used as a condition. If the statement evaluates to true or nonzero when this point is reached, execution stops.

colorPicker.comment: Invokes the platform-specific color selection dialog, and returns the selected color.

args.color: The color to be preselected in the dialog, as 0xRRGGBB, or -1 for the platform default.

gc.comment: Initiates garbage collection in the ExtendScript engine.

getenv.comment: Retrieves the value of an environment variable.

setenv.comment: Sets the value of an environment variable.

sleep.comment: Suspends the calling thread for a number of milliseconds. During a sleep period, checks at 100 millisecond intervals to see whether the sleep should be terminated. This can happen if there is a break request, or if the script timeout has expired.

toString.comment: Converts this object to a string.

args.text: The text to print. All arguments are concatenated.

writeln.comment: Prints text to the Console, and adds a newline character.

args.text: The text to print. All arguments are concatenated.

File.comment: Represents a file in the local file system in a platform-independent manner.

absoluteURI.comment: The full path name for the referenced file in URI notation.

alias.comment: If true, the object refers to a file system alias or shortcut.

created.comment: The creation date of the referenced file, or null if the object does not refer to a file on disk.

creator.comment: In Mac OS, the file creator as a four-character string. In Windows or UNIX, value is "????".

displayName.comment: The localized name of the referenced file, without the path specification.

encoding.comment: Gets or sets the encoding for subsequent read/write operations. One of the encoding constants listed in the JavaScript Tools Guide. If the value is not recognized, uses the system default encoding.A special encoder, BINARY, is used to read binary files. It stores each byte of the file as one Unicode character regardless of any encoding. When writing, the lower byte of each Unicode character is treated as a single byte to write.

eof.comment: When true, a read attempt caused the current position to be at the end of the file, or the file is not open.

error.comment: A string containing a message describing the most recent file system error. Typically set by the file system, but a script can set it. Setting this value clears any error message and resets the error bit for opened files. Contains the empty string if there is no error.

exists.comment: If true, this object refers to a file or file-system alias that actually exists in the file system.

fsName.comment: The platform-specific full path name for the referenced file.

fullName.comment: The full path name for the referenced file in URI notation.

hidden.comment: When true, the file is not shown in the platform-specific file browser. If the object references a file-system alias or shortcut, the flag is altered on the alias, not on the original file.

length.comment: The size of the file in bytes. Can be set only for a file that is not open, in which case it truncates or pads the file with 0-bytes to the new length.

lineFeed.comment: How line feed characters are written in the file system. One of the values "Windows", "Macintosh", or "Unix".

modified.comment: The date of the referenced file's last modification, or null if the object does not refer to a file on the disk.

name.comment: The file name portion of the absolute URI for the referenced file, without the path specification.

parent.comment: The Folder object for the folder that contains this file.

path.comment: The path portion of the absolute URI for the referenced file, without the file name.

readonly.comment: When true, prevents the file from being altered or deleted. If the referenced file is a file-system alias or shortcut, the flag is altered on the alias, not on the original file.

relativeURI.comment: The path name for the object in URI notation, relative to the current folder.

type.comment: The file type as a four-character string. In Mac OS, the Mac OS file type. In Windows, "appl" for .EXE files, "shlb" for .DLL files and "TEXT" for any other file.

changePath.comment: Changes the path specification of the referenced file.

args.path: A string containing the new path, absolute or relative to the current folder.

close.comment: Closes this open file. Returns true if the file was closed successfully, false if an I/O error occurred.

copy.comment: Copies this object's referenced file to the specified target location. Resolves any aliases to find the source file. If a file exists at the target location, it is overwritten. Returns true if the copy was successful.

args.target: A string with the URI path to the target location, or a File object that references the target location.

createAlias.comment: Makes this file a file-system alias or shortcut to the specified file. The referenced file for this object must not yet exist on disk. Returns true if the operation was successful.

args.path: A string containing the path of the target file.

execute.comment: Executes or opens this file using the appropriate application, as if it had been double-clicked in a file browser. You can use this method to run scripts, launch applications, and so on.Returns true immediately if the application launch was successful.

getRelativeURI.comment: Retrieves and returns the path for this file, relative to the specified base path, in URI notation. If no base path is supplied, the URI is relative to the path of the current folder.Returns a string containing the relative URI.

args.basePath: A base path in URI notation.

open.comment: Opens the referenced file for subsequent read/write operations. The method resolves any aliases to find the file. Returns true if the file was opened successfully.The method attempts to detect the encoding of the open file. It reads a few bytes at the current location and tries to detect the Byte Order Mark character 0xFFFE. If found, the current position is advanced behind the detected character and the encoding property is set to one of the strings UCS-2BE, UCS-2LE, UCS4-BE, UCS-4LE, or UTF-8. If the marker character is not found, it checks for zero bytes at the current location and makes an assumption about one of the above formats (except UTF-8). If everything fails, the encoding property is set to the system encoding. IMPORTANT: Be careful about opening a file more than once. The operating system usually permits you to do so, but if you start writing to the file using two different File objects, you can destroy your data.

args.mode: The read-write mode, a single-character string. One of these characters: r (read) Opens for reading. If the file does not exist or cannot be found, the call fails. w (write) Opens a file for writing. If the file exists, its contents are destroyed. If the file does not exist, creates a new, empty file. e (edit) Opens an existing file for reading and writing. a (append) Opens an existing file for reading and writing, and moves the current position to the end of the file.
args.type: In Mac OS, the type of a newly created file, a 4-character string. Ignored in Windows and UNIX.
args.creator: In Mac OS, the creator of a newly created file, a 4-character string. Ignored in Windows and UNIX.

openDlg.comment: Opens the built-in platform-specific file-browsing dialog, in which the user can select an existing file or files, and creates new File objects to represent the selected files. Differs from the class method openDialog() in that it presets the current folder to this File object's parent folder and the current file to this object's associated file. If the user clicks OK, returns a File or Folder object for the selected file or folder, or an array of objects. If the user cancels, returns null.

args.prompt: A string containing the prompt text, if the dialog allows a prompt.
args.filter: A filter that limits the types of files displayed in the dialog. In Windows,a filter expression such as "Javascript files:.jsx;All files:.". In Mac OS, a filter function that takes a File instance and returns true if the file should be included in the display, false if it should not.
args.multiSelect: When true, the user can select multiple files and the return value is an array.

read.comment: Reads the contents of the file, starting at the current position. Returns a string that contains up to the specified number of characters. If a number of characters is not supplied, reads from the current position to the end of the file. If the file is encoded, multiple bytes might be read to create single Unicode characters.

args.chars: An integer specifying the number of characters to read.

readch.comment: Reads a single text character from the file at the current position. Line feeds are recognized as CR, LF, CRLF or LFCR pairs.If the file is encoded, multiple bytes might be read to create a single Unicode character. Returns a string that contains the character.

readln.comment: Reads a single line of text from the file at the current position. Line feeds are recognized as CR, LF, CRLF or LFCR pairs.. If the file is encoded, multiple bytes might be read to create single Unicode characters. Returns a string that contains the text.

remove.comment: Deletes the file associated with this object from disk immediately, without moving it to the system trash. Does not resolve aliases; instead, deletes the referenced alias or shortcut file itself. Returns true if the file was successfully removed. IMPORTANT: Cannot be undone. It is recommended that you prompt the user for permission before deleting.

rename.comment: Renames the associated file. Does not resolve aliases, but renames the referenced alias or shortcut file itself. Returns true if the file was successfully renamed.

args.newName: The new file name, with no path information.

resolve.comment: Attempts to resolve the file-system alias or shortcut that this object refers to. If successful, creates and returns a new File object that points to the resolved file system element. Returns null if this object does not refer to an alias, or if the alias could not be resolved.

saveDlg.comment: Opens the built-in platform-specific file-browsing dialog, in which the user can select an existing file location to which to save information, and creates a new File object to represent the selected file. Differs from the class method saveDialog() in that it presets the current folder to this File object's parent folder and the file to this object's associated file. If the user clicks OK, returns a File object for the selected file. If the user cancels, returns null.

args.prompt: A string containing the prompt text, if the dialog allows a prompt.
args.filter: In Windows only, a filter that limits the types of files displayed in the dialog. In Windows only,a filter expression such as "Javascript files:.jsx;All files:.". Not used In Mac OS.

seek.comment: Seeks to a given position in the file. The new position cannot be less than 0 or greater than the current file size. Returns true if the position was changed.

args.pos: The new current position in the file as an offset in bytes from the start, current position, or end, depending on the mode.
args.mode: The seek mode. One of: 0: Seek to absolute position, where pos=0 is the first byte of the file. This is the default. 1: Seek relative to the current position. 2. Seek backward from the end of the file.

tell.comment: Retrieves the current position as a byte offset from the start of the file. Returns a number, the position index.

toSource.comment: Creates and returns a serialized string representation of this object. Pass the resulting string to eval() to recreate the object.

toString.comment: Converts this object to a string.

write.comment: Writes the specified text to the file at the current position. You can supply multiple text values; the strings are concatenated to form a single string.For encoded files, writing a single Unicode character may write multiple bytes. Returns true if the write was successful.IMPORTANT: Be careful not to write to a file that is open in another application or object, as this can overwrite existing data.

args.text: A text string to be written.

writeln.comment: Writes a string to the file at the current position and appends a line-feed sequence. You can supply multiple text values. The strings are concatenated into a single string, which is written in the file followed by one line-feed sequence, of the style specified by this object's linefeed property.For encoded files, writing a single Unicode character may write multiple bytes.Returns true if the write was successful.IMPORTANT: Be careful not to write to a file that is open in another application or object, as this can overwrite existing data.

args.text: A text string to be written.

Folder.comment: Represents a file-system folder or directory in a platform-independent manner.

absoluteURI.comment: The full path name for the referenced folder in URI notation.

alias.comment: When true, the object refers to a file system alias or shortcut.

created.comment: The creation date of the referenced folder, or null if the object does not refer to a folder on disk.

displayName.comment: The localized name portion of the absolute URI for the referenced folder, without the path specification.

error.comment: A message describing the most recent file system error. Typically set by the file system, but a script can set it. Setting this value clears any error message and resets the error bit for opened files. Contains the empty string if there is no error.

exists.comment: When true, this object refers to a folder that currently exists in the file system.

fsName.comment: The platform-specific name of the referenced folder as a full path name.

fullName.comment: The full path name for the referenced folder in URI notation. .

modified.comment: The date of the referenced folder's last modification, or null if the object does not refer to a folder on disk.

name.comment: The folder name portion of the absolute URI for the referenced file, without the path specification.

parent.comment: TThe Folder object for the folder that contains this folder, or null if this object refers to the root folder of a volume.

path.comment: The path portion of the object absolute URI for the referenced file, without the folder name.

relativeURI.comment: The path name for the referenced folder in URI notation, relative to the current folder.

changePath.comment: Changes the path specification of the referenced folder.

args.path: A string containing the new path, absolute or relative to the current folder.

create.comment: Creates a folder at the location given by this object's path property. Returns true if the folder was created.

execute.comment: Opens this folder in the platform-specific file browser (as if it had been double-clicked in the file browser). Returns true immediately if the folder was opened successfully.

getFiles.comment: Retrieves the contents of this folder, filtered by the supplied mask. Returns an array of File and Folder objects, or null if this object's referenced folder does not exist.

args.mask: A search mask for file names, specified as a string or a function. A mask string can contain question mark (?) and asterisk () wild cards. Default is "", which matches all file names. Can also be the name of a function that takes a File or Folder object as its argument. It is called for each file or folder found in the search; if it returns true, the object is added to the return array. NOTE: In Windows, all aliases end with the extension .lnk. ExtendScript strips this from the file name when found, in order to preserve compatibility with other operating systems. You can search for all aliases by supplying the search mask ".lnk", but note that such code is not portable.

getRelativeURI.comment: Retrieves and returns the path for this file, relative to the specified base path, in URI notation. If no base path is supplied, the URI is relative to the path of the current folder.Returns a string containing the relative URI.

args.basePath: A base path in URI notation.

remove.comment: Deletes the folder associated with this object from disk immediately, without moving it to the system trash. Folders must be empty before they can be deleted. Does not resolve aliases; instead, deletes the referenced alias or shortcut file itself. Returns true if the file was successfully removed. IMPORTANT: Cannot be undone. It is recommended that you prompt the user for permission before deleting.

rename.comment: Renames the associated folder. Does not resolve aliases, but renames the referenced alias or shortcut file itself. Returns true if the folder was successfully renamed.

args.newName: The new folder name, with no path information.

resolve.comment: Attempts to resolve the file-system alias or shortcut that this object refers to. If successful, creates and returns a new Folder object that points to the resolved file system element. Returns null if this object does not refer to an alias, or if the alias could not be resolved.

selectDlg.comment: Opens the built-in platform-specific file-browsing dialog, and creates a new File or Folder object for the selected file or folder. Differs from the class method selectDialog() in that it preselects this folder. If the user clicks OK, returns a File or Folder object for the selected file or folder. If the user cancels, returns null.

args.prompt: The prompt text, if the dialog allows a prompt.

toSource.comment: Creates and returns a serialized string representation of this object. Pass the resulting string to eval() to recreate the object.

toString.comment: Converts this object to a string.

addNamespace.comment: Adds a namespace declaration to the node. Returns the XML object itself.

appendChild.comment: Appends the given XML to this XML as a child. Returns the XML object itself. If the argument is not XML, creates a new XML element containing the argument as text. The element name of that new XML is the same as the last element in the original XML.

attribute.comment: Returns a list containing all attribute elements matching the given name.

args.name: The attribute name to look for.

attributes.comment: Returns a list containing all attribute elements.

child.comment: Returns a list containing all children of this XML matching the given element name. If the argument is a number, uses the number as index into the array of children.

args.name: The name or the index of the child element.

childIndex.comment: Returns a number representing the ordinal position of this XML object within the context of its parent.

children.comment: Returns an XML object containing all the properties of this XML object in order.

comments.comment: Returns an XML object containing the properties of this XML object that represent XML comments.

contains.comment: Checks if this XML object contains the given XML object.

copy.comment: Creates a copy of this XML object.

descendants.comment: Returns all the XML-valued descendants of this XML object with the given name. If the name parameter is omitted, returns all descendants of this XML object.

args.name: The name of the descendant to find.

elements.comment: Returns a list of XML children that are elements with a given name, or all children that are XML elements.

args.name: The element name. If not supplied, gets all children that are XML elements.

hasComplexContent.comment: Reports whether this XML object contains complex content. An XML object is considered to contain complex content if it represents an XML element that has child elements. XML objects representing attributes, comments, processing instructions and text nodes do not have complex content. The existence of attributes, comments, processing instructions and text nodes within an XML object is not significant in determining if it has complex content.

hasSimpleContent.comment: Reports whether this XML object contains simple content. An XML object is considered to contain simple content if it represents a text node, represents an attribute node or if it represents an XML element that has no child elements. XML objects representing comments and processing instructions do not have simple content. The existence of attributes, comments, processing instructions and text nodes within an XML object is not significant in determining if it has simple content.

inScopeNamespaces.comment: Returns an array of Namespace objects mirroring the current list of valid namespaces at this element. The last element of thereturned array is the default namespace.

insertChildAfter.comment: Inserts the given child2 after the given child1 in this XML object and returns this XML object. If child1 is null, the method inserts child2 before all children of this XML object (that is, after none of them). If child1 does not exist in this XML object, the method returns without modifying this XML object.

args.child1: The child to insert the other child after. If null, the method inserts child2 before all children of this XML object.

insertChildBefore.comment: Inserts the given child2 before the given child1 in this XML object and returns this XML object. If child1 is null, the method inserts child2 after all children of this XML object (that is, before none of them). If child1 does not exist in this XML object, the method returns without modifying this XML object.

args.child1: The child to search for. If null, the method inserts child2 after all children of this XML object.

length.comment: Returns the number of elements contained in an XML list. If this XML object is not a list, returns 1.

localName.comment: Returns the local name of this XML object. This value corresponds to the element name unless the name has a namespace prefix. For example, if the element has the name "ns:tag", the return value is "tag".

name.comment: Returns a QName object containing the URI and the local name of the element.

namespace.comment: Returns a Namespace object containing the namespace URI of the current element.

namespaceDeclarations.comment: Returns an array containing all namespace declarations of this XML object.

nodeKind.comment: Returns the type of this XML object as one of the strings "element", "attribute", "comment", "processing-instruction", or "text".

normalize.comment: Puts all text nodes in this and all descendant XML objects into a normal form by merging adjacent text nodes and eliminating empty text nodes. Returns this XML object.

parent.comment: Returns the parent object of this XML object. The root object, as returned by the XML constructor, does not have a parent and returns null. Note that the E4X standard does not define what happens if this XML object is a list containing elements with multiple parents.

prependChild.comment: Inserts a given child into this object before its existing XML properties, and returns this XML object.

processingInstructions.comment: Returns a list of preprocessing instructions. Collects processing-instructions with the given name, if supplied. Otherwise, returns an XML list containing all the children of this XML object that are processing-instructions regardless of their name.

args.name: The name of the preprocessing instruction to return.

removeNamespace.comment: Removes the given namespace from this XML, and returns this XML.

replace.comment: Replaces the value of specified XML properties of this XML object returns this XML object. This method acts like the assignment operator.

args.name: The property name. Can be a numeric property name, a name for a set of XML elements, or the properties wildcard “”. If this XML object contains no properties that match the name, the method returns without modifying this XML object.
args.value: The XML with which to replace the value of the matching property. Can be an XML object, XML list or any value that can be converted to a String with toString().

setChildren.comment: Replaces all of the XML-valued properties in this object with a new value, and returns this XML object.

args.value: The new value, which can be a single XML object or an XML list.

setLocalName.comment: Replaces the local name of this XML objectwith a string constructed from the given name The local name is any part behind a colon character. If there is no colon, it is the entire name.

setName.comment: Replaces the name of this XML object with the given QName object.

setNamespace.comment: Sets the namespace for this XML element. If the namespace has not been declared in the tree above this element, adds a namespace declaration.

text.comment: Returns an XML list containing all XML properties of this XML object that represent XML text nodes.

toString.comment: Returns the string representation of this object. For text and attribute nodes, this is the textual value of the node; for other elements, this is the result of calling the toXMLString() method. If this XML object is a list, concatenates the result of calling toString() on each element.

toXMLString.comment: Returns an XML-encoded string representation of this XML object. Always includes the start tag, attributes and end tag of the XML object regardless of its content. It is provided for cases when the default XML to string conversion rules are not desired. Interprets the global settings XML.prettyPrint and XML.prettyIndent.

xpath.comment: Evaluates the given XPath expression in accordance with the W3C XPath recommendation, using this XML object as the context node.

project.comment: This is the current active project.

isDocument.comment: Checks whether file specified is a doc

args.filePath: This is the path to be checked

audioTracks.comment: A collection of the sequence's audio tracks.

end.comment: Timecode (as a string) of the end of the sequence.

sequenceID.comment: Permanent ID of the sequence, within its project.

zeroPoint.comment: The starting timecode of the first frame of the sequence, as a string.

attachCustomProperty.comment: Adds a new metadata key to the sequence, and sets its value.

clone.comment: Clones a sequence. @returns the clone Sequence.

createSubsequence.comment: Creates a new sequence from the source sequence's in and out points.

args.ignoreMapping: If True the current selection, not track targeting, will determine the clips to include in the new sequence. If there is no selection, track targeting determines which clips are included in the new sequence.

exportAsFinalCutProXML.comment: Exports a new FCP XML file representing this sequence.

args.exportPath: The full file path (with file name) to create.
args.suppressUI: Optional; quiets any warnings or errors encountered during export.

exportAsMediaDirect.comment: Premiere Pro exports the sequence immediately.

exportAsProject.comment: Exports the sequence (and its constituent media) as a new PPro project.

args.path: Output file path, including file name.

getExportFileExtension.comment: Retrieves the file extension associated with a given output preset (.epr file).

getInPoint.comment: Retrieves the sequence's in point, as a timecode string.

getOutPoint.comment: Retrieves the sequence's out point, as a timecode string.

getInPointAsTime.comment: Retrieves the sequence's in point, as a `Time` object.

getOutPointAsTime.comment: Retrieves the sequence's out point, as a `Time` object.

getPlayerPosition.comment: Retrieves the current player position, as a `Time` object.

setInPoint.comment: Sets the in point of the sequence.

setOutPoint.comment: Sets the out point of the sequence.

args.pos: The new position, as a timecode string.

setZeroPoint.comment: Sets the timecode of the first frame of the sequence.

linkSelection.comment: Links the currently-selected `trackItems` together, if possible. @returns `True` if successful.

unlinkSelection.comment: Unlinks the currently-selected `trackItems`, if possible. @returns `True` if successful.

importMGT.comment: Imports a Motion Graphics Template (.mogrt) into the sequence

args.timeInTicks: Time (in ticks) at which to insert
args.videoTrackOffset: The offset from first video track to targeted track
args.audioTrackOffset: The offset from first audio track to targeted track @returns newly-created `trackItem` representing the .mogrt

isWorkAreaEnabled.comment: Returns `true` if work area is enabled.

setWorkAreaEnabled.comment: Sets the enabled state of the seqeuence work area.

getWorkAreaInPoint.comment: Returns the work area in point, in seconds.

setWorkAreaInPoint.comment: Specify the work area in point, in seconds.

getWorkAreaOutPoint.comment: Returns the work area out point, in seconds.

setWorkAreaOutPoint.comment: Specify the work area out point, in seconds.

getWorkAreaInPointAsTime.comment: Returns the work area in point, as a `Time` object.

setWorkAreaInPointAsTime.comment: Specify the work area in point, as `Time`.

getWorkAreaOutPointAsTime.comment: Returns the work area out point, as a `Time` object.

setWorkAreaOutPointAsTime.comment: Specify the work area out point, as `Time`.

insertClip.comment: Inserts a clip (`trackItem`) into the sequence.

args.vidTrackOffset: The offset from the first video track to targeted track
args.audTrackOffset: The offset from the first audio track to targeted track

getSelection.comment: Returns currently-selected clips, as an `Array` of `trackItems`

getSettings.comment: Returns the current sequence settings. @returns SequenceSettings

setSettings.comment: Specifies the sequence settings to use.

ProjectManagerOptions.comment: Structure containing all available options for the `ProjectManager`.

CLIP_TRANSFER_COPY.comment: Transfer mode setting: Copy source media

CLIP_TRANSFER_TRANSCODE.comment: Transfer mode setting: Transcode source media

CLIP_TRANSCODE_MATCH_PRESET.comment: Transcode mode setting: Transcode source media to a specific preset

CLIP_TRANSCODE_MATCH_CLIPS.comment: Transcode mode setting: Transcode source media to match clips

CLIP_TRANSCODE_MATCH_SEQUENCE.comment: Transcode mode setting: Transcode source media to match sequence settings

clipTranscoderOption.comment: Which transcode option to use; will be one of these: 	`CLIP_TRANSCODE_MATCH_PRESET`  `CLIP_TRANSCODE_MATCH_CLIPS` 	`CLIP_TRANSCODE_MATCH_SEQUENCE`

clipTransferOption.comment: Which transfer option to use; will be one of these: 	`CLIP_TRANSFER_COPY`  `CLIP_TRANSFER_TRANSCODE`

excludeUnused.comment: If `true`, projectItems not used in a sequence are not transferred

handleFrameCount.comment: The number of 'handle' frames to provide, before and after the in/out points of clips in the sequence.

includePreviews.comment: If `true`, preview files will also be transferred.

includeConformedAudio.comment: If `true`, conformed audio files will also be transferred.

renameMedia.comment: If `true`, media files will be renamed to match clip names.

destinationPath.comment: The containing directory for the consolidation/transfer.

includeAllSequences.comment: If `true`, all sequences in the project will be transferred.

affectedSequences.comment: An `Array` of all sequences affected by the transfer.

encoderPresetFilePath.comment: Path the the encoder preset (.epr file) to be used.

convertImageSequencesToClips.comment: If `true`, image sequences will be transcoded.

convertSyntheticsToClips.comment: If `true`, synthetic importer clips will be transcoded.

convertAECompsToClips.comment: If `true`, After Effects compositions will be transcoded.

copyToPreventAlphaLoss.comment: If `true`, source media will be copied not transcoded, if transcoding would have resulted in loss of alpha information.

errors.comment: An array of strings describing errors encountered.

args.arrayOfFilePathsToImport: An array of paths to files to import
args.suppressUI: optional; if true, suppress any warnings, translation reports, or errors.
args.projectBin: optional; if present, the bin into which to import the new media.
args.importAsNumberedStill: optiona; if present, interprets the file paths as a series of numbered stills.

args.projectPath: Path to project from which to import sequences.
args.sequences: An array of sequence IDs to import, from the project.

isSequence.comment: Returns whether the projectItem represents a sequence.@returns true, if projectItem is a sequence.

args.title: The title of the alert; ignored on the Macintosh
args.errorIcon: Display an Error icon; ignored on the Macintosh

confirm.comment: Displays an alert box with Yes and No buttons; returns true for Yes

args.noAsDefault: Set to true to set the No button as the default button
args.title: The title of the alert; ignored on the Macintosh

decodeURI.comment: Decodes a string created with encodeURI().

decodeURIComponent.comment: Decodes a string created with encodeURIComponent().

encodeURI.comment: Encodes a string after RFC2396. Create an UTF-8 ASCII encoded version of this string. The string is converted into UTF-8. Every non-alphanumeric character is encoded as a percent escape character of the form %xx, where xx is the hex value of the character. After the conversion to UTF-8 encoding and escaping, it is guaranteed that the string does not contain characters codes greater than 127. The list of characters not to be encoded is -_.!~'();/?:@&=+$,#. The method returns false on errors.

encodeURIComponent.comment: Encodes a string after RFC2396. Create an UTF-8 ASCII encoded version of this string. The string is converted into UTF-8. Every non-alphanumeric character is encoded as a percent escape character of the form %xx, where xx is the hex value of the character. After the conversion to UTF-8 encoding and escaping, it is guaranteed that the string does not contain characters codes greater than 127. The list of characters not to be encoded is -_.!~'(). The method returns false on errors.

escape.comment: Creates a URL-encoded string from aString. In the new string, characters of aString that require URL encoding are replaced with the format %xx, where xx is the hexadecimal value of the character code in the Unicode character set.This format is used to transmit information appended to a URL during, for example, execution of the GET method.Use the unescape() global function to translate the string back into its original format. Returns a string which is aString URL-encoded.

eval.comment: Evaluates its argument as a JavaScript script, and returns the result of evaluation. You can pass the result of an object's toSource() method to reconstruct that object.

isFinite.comment: Evaluates an expression and reports whether the result is a finite number. Returns true if the expression is a finite number, false otherwise. False if the value is infinity or negative infinity.

isNaN.comment: Evaluates an expression and reports whether the result is "Not-a-Number" (NaN). Returns true if the result of evaluation is not a number (NaN), false if the value is a number.

isXMLName.comment: Returns true if the supplied string is a valid XML name.

localize.comment: Localizes a ZString-encoded string and merges additional arguments into the string.

args.what: The string to localize. A ZString-encoded string that can contain placeholder for additional arguments in the form %1 to %n.
args.arguments: Optional argument(s) to be merged into the string. There may be more than one argument.

parseFloat.comment: Extracts a floating-point number from a string. Parses a string to find the first set of characters that can be converted to a floating point number, and returns that number, or NaN if it does not encounter characters that it can converted to a number.The function supports exponential notation.

args.text: The string from which to extract a floating point number.

parseInt.comment: Extracts an integer from a string. Parses a string to find the first set of characters, in a specified base, that can be converted to an integer, and returns that integer, or NaN if it does not encounter characters that it can convert to a number.

args.text: The string from which to extract an integer.
args.base: The base of the string to parse (from base 2 to base 36). If not supplied, base is determined by the format of string.

prompt.comment: Displays a dialog allowing the user to enter text Returns null if the user cancelled the dialog, the text otherwise

args.default_: The default text to preset the edit field with
args.title: The title of the dialog;

setDefaultXMLNamespace.comment: Defines the default XML namespace. This is a replacement function for the standard JavaScript statement set default xml namespace.

args.namespace: The namespace to use. Omit this parameter to return to the empty namespace. This is either a Namespace object or a string.

unescape.comment: Translates URL-encoded string into a regular string, and returns that string. Use the escape() global function to URL-encode strings.

uneval.comment: Creates a source code representation of the supplied argument, and returns it as a string.
